book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Keep the dangerous opponent off lead
key_insight: This is a fascinating problem since the winning move may turn out the only way to lose a cold game. Duck the jack of clubs. Now you have to find North with three spades or a doubleton honour to drive the game home
solution_summary: Order of play: 1. Duck the jack of clubs. Now you have to find North with three spades or a doubleton honour to drive the game home. If clubs break 2-2 and South holds Q-J-x of spades, we will go down in a game that our grandma would make. 2. Win the diamond switch with the ace and pitch a heart. 3-4. Play the ace of spades and a spade to the ten. If South raises with an honour win the trick with the king and concede a spade.
making_contract: The Belgian pair stopped in 2♠, +140 for EW. You ducked the jack of clubs: +620 = +10 IMP.
educational_value: Learn when making the seemingly wrong play is actually the only way to succeed

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Keep the dangerous opponent off lead
key_insight: On the first trick you duck the queen of diamonds. Then it is easy. You will draw trumps, eliminate diamonds and endplay North on the third round of clubs
solution_summary: On the first trick you duck the queen of diamonds. Then it is easy. You will draw trumps, eliminate diamonds and endplay North on the third round of clubs.
making_contract: Closed room – Contract 4♠, +420 for EW. You ducked the queen of diamonds: no swing.
educational_value: Learn to duck early tricks to set up elimination and endplay sequences

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
key_insight: Take your ace of hearts on the first trick, aiming to block the opponents' suit, and play a club. The contract is cold unless North led ♥3 from a holding such as K-Q-J-3-2
solution_summary: Take your ace of hearts on the first trick, aiming to block the opponents' suit, and play a club. The contract is cold unless North led ♥3 from a holding such as K-Q-J-3-2.
making_contract: Closed room – Contract 3NT, +600 for EW. You took the ace of hearts on the first trick: no swing.
educational_value: Learn when to block opponent suits by winning early tricks

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Let the opponents work for you
key_insight: Win the trick with the ace of hearts. Play a spade and if South play an honour then we can safely eliminate hearts. The king of hearts ruffed and a heart ruffed. The king of diamonds and a diamond to the ace. A heart ruffed and a spade
solution_summary: Order of play: 1. Win the trick with the ace of hearts. 2. Play a spade and if South play an honour then we can safely eliminate hearts. 3-4. The king of hearts ruffed and a heart ruffed. 5-6. The king of diamonds and a diamond to the ace 7-8. A heart ruffed and a spade. If South had king-queen doubleton in the trump suit and three hearts then we make the game without finding the queen of clubs.
making_contract: Closed room – contract 4♠, +620 for EW. You worked out the elimination: no swing.
educational_value: Learn complex elimination plays and how to avoid guessing key cards

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
key_insight: Cross to your hand with a trump (they break 1-1). Play the jack of hearts, ruffing the queen. Play three rounds of diamonds with a ruff. Play ♥9 – if North does not cover with ♥10 discard a club and the contract is home
solution_summary: Order of play: 2-3. Cross to your hand with a trump (they break 1-1). Play the jack of hearts, ruffing the queen. 4-6. Play three rounds of diamonds with a ruff. 7. Play ♥9 – if North does not cover with ♥10 discard a club and the contract is home. 8-9. Ruff ♥10 if North covers and return to your hand with a trump. Play ♠8. If North does not cover duck the eight. If North covers, take a trick with the ace of clubs. 10-11. Again enter your hand with a trump and play to the queen of clubs. Why did we need all these club manoeuvres? This was an extra chance for the king of clubs doubleton with South.
alternate_result: You were not too careful: −10 IMP.
educational_value: Learn to combine multiple chances and preserve extra possibilities in slam contracts

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Plan the whole hand before playing to the first trick
key_insight: Play the jack of spades. If you make the mistake of ducking in the dummy, you will doom the contract if South raises with the queen. Now play the king and another club
solution_summary: Order of play: 1. Play the jack of spades. If you make the mistake of ducking in the dummy, you will doom the contract if South raises with the queen. 2-3. Now play the king and another club. Even if North holds up the ace of clubs for one round and switches to hearts, you will have a quick entry to your hand (the ten of spades) to discard a heart loser on the established jack of clubs.
making_contract: Closed room – Contract 3NT (E), Lead 6♠, +400 for EW. You played the jack: no swing.
Educational_value: Learn the importance of planning the whole hand from trick one

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Make a careful plan at the beginning
key_insight: Tricks 2,3,4: Play ace, king and another diamond, rounds ruffing with ♠9. Analyse what may happen. North will ruff with a singleton honour. Does not matter. Cross to the dummy and play your diamonds through South trumps
solution_summary: Order of play: Tricks 2,3,4: Play ace, king and another diamond, rounds ruffing with ♠9. Analyse what may happen. North will ruff with a singleton honour. Does not matter. Cross to the dummy and play your diamonds through South trumps.
making_contract: Closed room – the Belgian pair stopped in 3NT, +660 for EW. Your play was effective: +12 IMP
educational_value: Learn to make careful plans involving trump overruffs and suit establishment

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
key_insight: Win with the king of diamonds. Concede a heart! Yes, that's correct, duck in both hands. Win the diamond return and play a heart to the queen. A 4-2 break with the king offside is not a problem anymore
solution_summary: Order of play: 1. Win with the king of diamonds. 2. Concede a heart! Yes, that's correct, duck in both hands. Win the diamond return and play a heart to the queen. A 4-2 break with the king offside is not a problem anymore. (If instead you play a heart to the queen on the first round, South will defeat you by holding up.)
making_contract: We all know safety play rules: – no swing.
alternate_result: If you forgot the rules: −10 IMP.
educational_value: Learn safety play rules and how to maintain communications in NT contracts

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
opening_lead: ♦6. You played the ♠A and the king fell from South
main_technique: Determine a defender's shape to prepare for a trump coup
key_insight: The winning layouts with North: 4-3-3-3, 4-4-2-3 and 4-4-3-2. You have to adjust your play to these layouts. Begin with three rounds of hearts. a) 4 – 3 – 3 – 3 Ruff two diamonds, draw clubs in three rounds and stay in your hand. Playing the fourth heart crowns the work
solution_summary: The winning layouts with North: 4-3-3-3, 4-4-2-3 and 4-4-3-2. You have to adjust your play to these layouts. Begin with three rounds of hearts. a) 4 – 3 – 3 – 3 Ruff two diamonds, draw clubs in three rounds and stay in your hand. Playing the fourth heart crowns the work. b) 4 – 4 – 2 – 3 Ruff a heart and a diamond, draw clubs in three rounds and play ♠8. c) 4 – 4 – 3 – 2 Ruff two diamonds and a heart and play clubs in three rounds. You have to guess whether North has shape b) or c). The opponents' discards will be helpful.
making_contract: The Belgian pair stopped quite rightly in 4♠, +450 for EW. You managed to endplay: +11 IMP.
Educational_value: Learn advanced trump coup technique and how to determine defender distribution

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship part 1
author: Krzysztof Martens
main_technique: Attack the entry to the dangerous hand
key_insight: Win with the queen of spades. Play the jack of diamonds. Duck the first spade return and win the third round. Now you can safely finesse in hearts
solution_summary: Order of play: 1. Win with the queen of spades. 2. Play the jack of diamonds. 3-4. Duck the first spade return and win the third round. Now you can safely finesse in hearts. Playing correctly brought no swing. If you played a heart to the ace and finessed the diamond king: −12 IMP. Why? South will duck a heart you are going to play.
alternate_result: If you played a heart to the ace and finessed the diamond king: −12 IMP. Why? South will duck a heart you are going to play. You had to work hard to stay level on the first seven boards. In the remaining three you could earn 33 IMP = 22-8 VP. On the ninth round Ireland will be your opponents.
educational_value: Learn to attack entries to dangerous hands and preserve your own entries for finesses
